ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live lecture twice a week over Zoom plus a weekly Zoom discussion section
live section meeting
There was also a virtual discussion section.
weekly discussion sections
Some required media viewings/listenings.
discussion section
There were also a weekly discussion sections
Recorded lecture, discussion section
Combination of live virtual lecture and weekly virtual seminar
Live virtual lecture & weekly live virtual discussion section
Live virtual lecture + virtual section (mandatory)

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned more about the origins and history of American protest music
I learned about the political histories surrounding black protest music, as well about the lives of artists and authors who created protest music.
I learned a lot about listening to music with a critical ear. This course taught me a lot about resistance through artistic expression and also about art as a mode of survival.
The history of African-American culture and music.
I learned so much about american history and about how to analyze music
The biggest skill I learned from this course were the skills necessary to analyze music. I've learned a lot about the evolution of protest music and its relation to modern and historical events.

This class gave me insight into the power of music in protest both in the past and the present. It allowed me to consider the importance of music as an independent means of generating and sustaining knowledge, providing hope, and critiquing systems of oppression.
Because of this course I am now knowledgeable to the history of black protest music. I also know of key figures that contributed to the black freedom struggle.
Understanding of how Black music intertwines with history and culture in the US, ability to critically analyze music in context and make connections between artists and styles

AFAM 190 introduced me not only to a wide variety of historical and contemporary black performers, but also gave me an understanding of the evolution of black musicfrom blues to jazz to hip-hopand the interactions between different genres over decades. The course was also an amazing opportunity to write analytically about music that inspired me and explore its connections with other forms of scholarship.

I learned so much about Black modes of protest through and adjacent to music historically in America. I learned how to critically analyze performances, songs, sound, literature and put diverse pieces in conversation with each other. Could spend hours writing about everything I learned.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The subject matter of the class was definitely interesting and I appreciated that Professor Brooks spanned across so many eras and genres in our discussion of protest music. Something that I really struggled with on Zoom was Professor Brooks' decision to play music underneath her talking during the lecture. I spent much of the semester unable to hear what she was saying and it was extremely overwhelming having two different sounds coming from the same speakers and having no control over it. I definitely feel like I lost a lot because of that. Also, the amount of reading seemed to be unnecessarily much as it was often unclear how certain material tied into the class and we often didn't cover large chunks of it. I would have wanted a more clear overarching theme or argument that each class worked to further prove or analyze because the separate classes felt a bit disjointed and I was looking for a more clear through line to help me really know what the purpose of the class actually was.

Strengths: I felt like the class was always making historical examples relevant to today's political climate. I also appreciated the creative options for the midterm and final assignments.
Weaknesses: WAY too much reading. It was so hard to know which course material to focus on from week to week, so the syllabus felt very overwhelming

I think this course tried to take on too much. There was far too much reading each week, and it became challenging to figure out what reading was essential and was unnecessary. Every text was one I would have loved to dedicate time too, but I could never get to all of them. I think the strength of this course was Professor Brooks. In all ways she is an amazing and engaged teacher.

The strengths were the professor and her teaching, and the course is very interesting. Sometimes because of the readings, however, I feel that attention was taken away from the music, which is unfortunate in a class about Protest Music.
The course was sound in structure and acquiring participation from students even in the Zoom format.

Sometimes I struggled to maintain interest during the zoom lectures, and it was often hard to pay attention to the lectures. However the format of lecture over playing music made learning much easier as well, and allowed me to practice my own analytical skills during the lecture.
This course was one of my favorite courses at Yale. The lectures were consistently engaging and sections were always helpful.

The course lecture was, at times, hard to follow because of how little student engagement there was; students were rarely asked to participate in lecture, which disregarded accountability. It was very easy to skip live lectures. In addition, the assignmentsespecially those that required readingwere hard to keep up with because of the length and the multitude of topics that were covered in one day.

Though I greatly enjoyed the subject matter and lectures themselves, I felt as though the grade breakdown and workload of the course was very uneven and would have liked more opportunities for feedback throughout.

Strengths: really interesting material, passionate professor and teaching staff, fun and uplifting and illuminating. Weaknesses: lecture felt a little too general sometimes, I wish it had more detail about music theory and the actual definitions and genealogies of types of music, and gave us more solid a sense of what we should be listening for

I loved this course, and I believe it went as well as it couldve, given the limitations of a virtual semester. The one weakness of the course was that we perhaps attempted to cover too much material for one semester, but in the context of this course, that was a good problem to have.

The material is amazing, Professor Brooks is an absolute gem, and the TFs are really great. The only issue was that the reading assignments were pretty large, but the TFs helped manage that by telling you what readings for the week you should focus on. Incredible class, I got the chills multiple times every single class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Brooks tried facilitating discussion through the Zoom chat, but it never worked

I think synchronous lecture was effective. I thought the music in the background was less successful, but I still liked having it. I would have loved to have this course in person, but on zoom the hour and fifteen minute lecture length became a challenge. I would have opted for three shorter lectures or two shorter and one recorded just to maintain focus.
The Zoom lectures were a bit shaky regarding audio. I don't think my professor could tell when the music she was playing was too loud or not. It wasn't enough to hinder learning however.
The lectures were recorded, but not immediately available in the cloud like some of my other lectures.
we had problems with the audio sometimes, headphones may be helpful for professors to have

I thought the online discussion sections helped my analytical skills improve even better, and gave me access to varying opinions from other students which only furthered my growth. I felt like the lectures struggled with keeping me engaged. I'm not sure what would could change, but I struggled with the online format in this class.
I think one thing that would be useful would be providing more of the course materials in the files. Living outside of the US, it was sometimes difficult to access all of the readings.

I really love Professor Brooks but I just think it was A LOT to cover during a pandemic. Like I honestly couldn't even devote any substantial mental energy to it after a few weeks because it was just too much content. All of the information was of course very timely and important, but I do think that sometimes less is more in a pandemic school year.
Recorded lectures were super helpful in taking into account the situations of all students.
Lectures and sections were well done overall! Audio was a bit of an issue in lecture especially in terms of volume, but Professor Brooks and the UTA worked really hard to improve
I think this course went as well as it couldve given the limitations of a virtual lecture. Discussion sections & readings during lecture provided opportunities for student engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was definitely interesting, but not world-changing for me. I enjoyed listening to and learning about the music

Maybe? Probably not if it's online the next time it's taught because of the difficulty to hear Professor Brooks over the music. I think if you take this class you have to be extremely engaged in the material and lectures and ok with a class that feels a bit disjointed at times.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn more context behind the Black Lives Matter movement, as well as any musician who wants to broaden their perspective on the purpose and power of music in a political context.
Yes!! Learned so much black music history from a super knowledgeable and engaging professor!
I would recommend any course taught by professor Brooks. This may be lower on the list than others of her classes, however.
Yes, because it is very important history to know, if you just enjoy any type of music. And Professor Brooks is an incredible lecturer.
Yes.

I would recommend this course to another student. Especially in a traditional classroom format, the material would be very interesting. Furthermore, the skills that I've acquired in this class are really valuable, and helped me grow in my other classes as well.
Yes! This class was so engaging and it was so eye-opening to consider many of the songs I grew up listening to in a new light. Professor Brooks and the TFs are iconic.

I would 100% recommend this course to other students because of how passionate and dedicated Professor Brooks and the Teacher Fellows are. The course material is so relevant to today's fight for equality amongst minorities, specifically the black population. The class allowed me to be informed of current events and, at the same time, be a part of the Black Lives Matter protest.
yeah cool class
Yes! The subject matter is so incredibly relevant today!
Yes overall, really interesting and outside the box and you get to listen to amazing music
Yes! Even for those not necessarily interested in music or in black history, this class is incredibly engaging and eye-opening, especially under Prof. Brooks masterful leadership.
100% YES
